meaning: The beauty of the heart reflects on the face.

proverb: அகல இருந்தால் நிகள உறவு, கிட்டவந்தால் முட்டப் பகை
transliteration: Agala irunthaal nigal uravu, kitta vandhaal mutta pagai
meaning: Distance maintains friendship, closeness may cause quarrel.

transliteration: Agala uzhu girathai vida aazha uzhu
meaning: Plough deep rather than wide.
A wide halo foretells daytime rain.

proverb: அசைந்து தின்கிறது யானை, அசையாமல் தின்கிறது வீடு
transliteration: Asaindhu thinggiradhu yaanai, asaiyaamal thinggiradhu veedu
meaning: An elephant eats by moving, a house is eaten by staying still (decay).
The fearless will even climb the stage.
A cart without an axle-pin will not move.
What didn't bend at five won't bend at fifty.
Modesty is a woman's beauty.
The restrained are wise; the unrestrained are like stone.
One who does wrong will suffer in return.

proverb: அடி நாக்கிலே நஞ்சும் நுனி நாக்கில் அமுதமும்
transliteration: Adi naakkile nanjum nuni naakkil amudhamum
meaning: The base of the tongue holds poison, the tip holds nectar.

proverb: அடி மேல் அடி அடித்தால் அம்மியும் நகரும்
transliteration: Adi mel adi adithaal ammiyum nagarum
meaning: Repeated blows will even move a grinding stone.

proverb: அடி உதவுவது போல் அண்ணன் தம்பி உதவ மாட்டார்கள்
transliteration: Adi uthavuvadhu pol annan thambi uthava maattaargal
meaning: Brothers may not help like a beating stick does in herding.
An untrained cow will not obey.

proverb: அடுத்த வீட்டுக்காரனுக்கு அதிகாரம் வந்தால் அண்டை வீட்டுக்காரனுக்கு இரைச்சல் இலாபம்
transliteration: Adutha veettukkaaranu kku adhigaaram vandhaal andai veettukkaaranu kku iraichchal ilaabam
meaning: When a neighbor gets power, the next neighbor suffers noise.
A squirrel on a branch, a tortoise in a well (safe in their place).
A flood that crossed the dam won't return by crying.
When you split a fig, it’s full of worms.
Evening rain won't stop for tears.
A father's worth is known after he is gone.
Practice never destroys knowledge.

proverb: அயலூரானுக்கு ஆற்றோரம் பயம், உள்ளூரானுக்கு மரத்திடியில் பயம்
transliteration: Ayalooranukku aatrroram bayam, ullooranukku maraththidiyil bayam
meaning: An outsider fears the riverbank, a local fears under the tree (each has their own dangers).
A country without a king is like a cart without an axle.

proverb: அரிசி ஆழாக்கானாலும் அடுப்புக் கட்டி மூன்று வேண்டும்
transliteration: Arisi aazhaakkaanaalum aduppu katti moonru vendum
meaning: Even if rice is abundant, three stones are needed for the stove.
Even a buffalo won't stay in a valueless house.

proverb: அழிந்த கொல்லையில் குதிரை மேய்ந்தாலென்ன, கழுதை மேய்ந்தாலென்ன?
transliteration: Azhindha kollaiyil kuthirai meyindhaal enna, kazhudai meyindhaal enna
meaning: In a ruined field, what difference if horses or donkeys graze?
Don't trust a crying man or a laughing woman.
The crying baby gets the milk.
Even if she cries, the child must be delivered by the mother.
Will the measuring pot know the grain’s inside value?
Even nectar becomes poison in excess.
A pious merchant plants fully (invests with virtue).

proverb: அள்ளிக் கொடுத்தால் சும்மா, அளந்து கொடுத்தால் கடன்
transliteration: Alli koduthaal summaa, alandhu koduthaal kadan
meaning: Giving freely is charity; giving measured is a loan.
Despite efforts to fly, there's no mat to sleep on (hardship).

proverb: அறப்படித்தவன் அங்காடி போனால், விற்கவும் மாட்டான் கொள்ளவும் மாட்டான்
transliteration: Arappadiththavan angaadi ponaal, virkkavum maattaan kolavum maattaan
meaning: An untrained seller in the market neither sells nor buys.
If virtue is squeezed, it will be lost.

transliteration: Arindharindhu seygira paavaththai azhuthazhuthu tholaikka vendum
meaning: A knowing sin must be repented with tears until erased.
Does anyone perish by knowing more?
The friendship of the ignorant is considered the highest burden.
Even if the wise advise a thousand times, the ignorant fail.
Do not seek wisdom among the ignorant.
The ignorant have neither knowledge nor bravery.
Even a king desires the wise.

proverb: அறுபத்து நாலடிக் கம்பத்திலேறி ஆடினாலும், அடியில் இறங்கித்தான் தியாகம் வாங்கவேண்டும்
transliteration: Arupathu naaladi kambaththileriy aadi naalum, adiyil irangith thaan thyagam vaangavendum
meaning: Even if you dance atop a tall pole, you must come down to receive your reward.

transliteration: Arupuk kaalaththil elikku aindhu penn saadhi
meaning: In harvest time, a rat has five wives (abundance brings choices).
Little knowledge is a store of trouble.
With love, even the impossible becomes possible.
Would one erase what he wrote yesterday to write again?

proverb: அன்று குடிக்கத் தண்ணீர் இல்லை ஆனைமேல் அம்பாரி வேணுமாம்
transliteration: Andru kudik kath thanneer illai aanai mel ambari veenum aam
meaning: No water to drink yesterday, but wants a howdah today.
One who doesn’t help his mother will not help anyone.
Can you slap in the house of the one who offered food?
Those who bear creation will not bear ruin.
A man without clothes is half a man.
An angry man has limited wisdom.

proverb: ஆய்ந்து பாராதான் காரியந் தான் சாந்துயரந் தரும்
transliteration: Aayndhu paaraadhaan kaariyam thaan saanthuyaram tharum
meaning: Unexamined work brings regret.
Misfortune can come by hand or by mouth.
Even while enjoying, keep an eye on the task.

proverb: ஆலும் வேலும் பல்லுக்குறுதி, நாலும் இரண்டும் சொல்லுக்குறுதி
transliteration: Aalum velum palluk kurudhi, naalum irandum solluk kurudhi
meaning: Certain trees harm the teeth; certain words harm speech.

proverb: ஆலை இல்லாத ஊரிலே இலுப்பைப் பூ சக்கரை
transliteration: Aalai illaadha oorile iluppaip poo sakkarai
meaning: In a town without a mill, the iluppai flower is sugar.
Do not step without knowing the depth.

proverb: ஆவும் தென்னையும் ஐந்து வருடத்தில் பலம் தரும்
transliteration: Aavum thennaiyum aindhu varudaththil palam tharum
meaning: The cow and the coconut tree bear fruits in five years.
Beauty is wasted on a girl without a guardian.
Even if the soldier is few, the weapon is sharp.
Death can come at six or at a hundred (anytime).
Yesterday’s porridge is stale porridge.

proverb: ஆறு கடக்கிறவரையில் அண்ணன் தம்பி, ஆறு கடந்தால் நீ யார் நான் யார்?
transliteration: Aaru kadakkiravaraiyil annan thambi, aaru kadandhaal nee yaar naan yaar
meaning: Until we cross the river, we are brothers; after that, strangers.
Even when throwing into the river, measure before you throw.

proverb: ஆற்றில் ஒரு கால் சேற்றில் ஒரு கால்
transliteration: Aatril oru kaal saetrril oru kaal
meaning: One foot in the river, one foot in the mud.

proverb: ஆறுகெட நாணல் இடு, ஊரு கெட நூலை விடு
transliteration: Aaru keda naanl idu, ooru keda noolai vidu
meaning: To destroy a river, plant reeds; to destroy a village, spread gossip.

proverb: ஆறு போவதே போக்கு அரசன் சொல்வதே தீர்ப்பு
transliteration: Aaru povadhe pokku arasan solvadhdhe theerppu
meaning: The river flows as usual; the king’s word is the final verdict.
A black elephant is worth a thousand gold coins.

proverb: ஆனைக்கு ஒரு காலம் பூனைக்கு ஒரு காலம்
transliteration: Aanaikku oru kaalam poonaikku oru kaalam
meaning: Every creature has its time — elephant and cat alike.
Even an elephant can slip.
When an elephant lies down, it levels people too.

proverb: ஆனை வரும் பின்னே, மணி ஓசை வரும் முன்னே
transliteration: Aanai varum pinne, mani osai varum munne
meaning: The bell’s sound is heard before the elephant arrives.
The grass is greener on the other side.

proverb: இங்கே தலை காட்டுகிறான், அங்கே வால் காட்டுகிறான்
transliteration: Inge thalai kaattugiraan, ange vaal kaattugiraan
meaning: Shows his head here and his tail there — acts differently in different places.
Profit in ginger, loss in turmeric — gains in one, loss in another.
Give him space, he will take over the whole place.

proverb: இட்ட உறவு எட்டு நாளைக்கு நக்கின உறவு நாலு நாலைக்கு
transliteration: Itta uravu ettu naalaikku nakkina uravu naalu naalaikku
meaning: A made friendship lasts long, a bitten one lasts short.
One who gave never perished.
Givers are noble, non-givers are of low character.
A blink’s fault is not seen by the eye.
Even if you go to pity, go with pride.
Do not put your leg in two boats.

proverb: இரவற் சீலையை நம்பி இடுப்புக் கந்தையை எறியாதே
transliteration: Iravaar seelayai nambi iduppuk kandhaiyai eriyaadhe
meaning: Do not throw away your waist cloth depending on the night’s blanket.

proverb: இராகு திசையில் வாழ்ந்தவனும் இல்லை; இராச திசையில் கெட்டவணுமில்லை
transliteration: Iraagu thisaiyil vaazhnthavanum illai, raasa thisaiyil kettavanum illai
meaning: None prosper facing north, none fail facing east.
Even if a king’s daughter, she is still a wife to her husband.
What is the use of a fly where iron is hammered?

proverb: இரும்பு பிடித்த கையும் சிரங்கு பிடித்த கையும் சும்மா இரா
transliteration: Irumbu piditha kaiyum sirangu piditha kaiyum summa ira
meaning: The hand on iron and the hand on sores are both restless.

proverb: இராமனைப்போல் இராசா இருந்தால் அனுமானைப்போல் சேவகனும் இருப்பான்
transliteration: Raamanai pol raasa irundhaal Hanumanai pol sevaganum iruppaan
meaning: A king like Rama will have a servant like Hanuman.
Friendship needs the patience of at least one.
What does not exist is neither gained nor lost.
Will a bride cut her sacred thread just for a loss?
A dragging song needs good music.
A young calf knows no fear.
Youth is like stone (strong and unyielding).
Learning in youth is like engraving on stone.
Learning in youth is like inscription on sculpture.
Laziness in youth brings regret in old age.
Drink medicine at the right time.
When tight it’s gruel, when loose it’s porridge — things change with conditions.

proverb: இறைக்க ஊறும் மணற்கேணி, ஈயப் பெருகும் பெருஞ்செல்வம்
transliteration: Iraikka oorum manarkkeni, iyap perugum perun selvam
meaning: Like a sandy well that overflows when poured, wealth increases by giving.
Only a flowing spring overflows.
Species with their own kind, goats with goats.

proverb: இன்றைக்கு இலை அறுத்தவன் நாளைக்கு குலை அறுப்பான்
transliteration: Indraikku ilai aruththavan naalaikku kulai aruppaan
meaning: One who cuts leaves today will cut the bunch tomorrow.

proverb: ஈக்கு விடம் தலையில், தேளுக்கு விடம் கொடுக்கில்
transliteration: Eekku vidam thalaiyil, theelukku vidam kodukkil
meaning: Place flies on the head, give scorpions poison — improper actions.

proverb: ஈட்டி எட்டு முழம் பாயும் பணம் பாதாளம் மட்டும் பாயும்
transliteration: Eetti ettu muzham paayum, panam paadhaalam mattum paayum
meaning: A spear leaps eight spans, money plunges to the abyss.
The ungiving invite evil people.
The wet tongue has no bones.

proverb: உடல் உள்ள வரையில் கடல் கொள்ளாத கவலை
transliteration: Udal ulla varaiyil kadal kollaadha kavalai
meaning: As long as there is life, do not worry about the ocean's depth.

proverb: உடம்பு போனால் போகிறது கை வந்தால் போதும்
transliteration: Udambu ponaal pogiradhu, kai vandhaal podhum
meaning: If health is lost it goes, but having the skill is enough.
Wealth and poverty are never constant.

proverb: உடையவன் பாரா வேலை ஒரு முழங் கட்டை
transliteration: Udaiyavan paaraa velai oru muzham kattai
meaning: A careless rich man’s work is like a short log — incomplete.
Can a broken conch produce music?

proverb: உண்ட உடம்பிற்கு உறுதி, உழுத புலத்தில் நெல்லு
transliteration: Unda udampirku urudhi, uzhu p pulaththil nellu
meaning: A fed body gains strength, a ploughed field yields paddy.
If you sit, eventually you must lie down (rest follows work).
If you have food at home, don’t think of a banquet elsewhere.
The beauty of eating is in sharing a feast.

transliteration: Undu kozhu thaal nandu valaiyil iraadhu
meaning: If it grows fat, the crab won’t fit in the net.
Unused property turns to dust.

proverb: உண்ணீர் உண்ணீரென்றே ஊட்டாதார் தம் மனையில் உண்ணாமை கோடி பெறும்
transliteration: Unneer unneer endre oottaathaar than manaiyil unnaamai kodi perum
meaning: One who keeps saying ‘eat’ but never serves will face famine in their house.
Friendship on the lips, enmity in the heart.

proverb: உத்திராடத்தில் ஒரு பிள்ளையும், ஊர் வாரியில் ஒரு நிலமும்
transliteration: Uththiraadaththil oru pillaiyum, oor vaarikil oru nilamum
meaning: A child in the Uttiradam star and land on village edge are rare treasures.
Remember the one who fed you till your last breath.

transliteration: Uyara uyara parandhaalum oork kuruvi parunthaagumaa
meaning: Even flying high, can a sparrow become a hawk?
A real friend is one who saves your life.
What falls in the mortar can it escape the pestle?
Rolling, turning, and pressing enhance the quality.
A greedy person spends twice.

proverb: உழுகிற நாளில் ஊருக்குப் போனால், அறுக்கிற நாளில் ஆள் தேவையில்லை
transliteration: Uzhugira naalil oorukku ponaal, arukira naalil aal thevai illai
meaning: If you go to the village on ploughing day, no one needs you on harvest day.

transliteration: Uzhudavan kanakku paarththaal uzha kkenum minjaadhu
meaning: If the ploughman counts, there will be nothing left to plough.
There is no theft without prior spying.

proverb: உள்ளது சொல்ல ஊரு மல்ல நல்லது சொல்ல நாடுமல்ல
transliteration: Ulladhu solla ooru malla, nalladhu solla naadum malla
meaning: A town may not accept the truth, and even a nation may not accept goodness.
What you have won’t go, what you don’t have won’t come.
When the heart burns, the lips utter old words.
Why buy ghee when you have butter in the pot?

proverb: உறவு போகாமல் கெட்டது கடன் கேட்காமல் கெட்டது
transliteration: Uravu pogamal kettavai kadan ketkaamal kettavai
meaning: Relations spoil without contact, finances spoil without asking.

proverb: ஊசியைக் காந்தம் இழுக்கும் உத்தமனைச் சிநேகம் இழுக்கும்
transliteration: Oosiyai kaantham ilukkum, uththamananai snegam ilukkum
meaning: As a magnet pulls a needle, goodness pulls friendship.
He who is early for meals is late for work.
Without food, the body perishes.

proverb: ஊர் உண்டு பிச்சைக்கு, குளம் உண்டு தண்ணீருக்கு
transliteration: Oor undu pichchaikku, kulam undu thanneerukku
meaning: There is a village for alms and a pond for water.
There’s no furnace lid to close the village’s mouth (rumors can’t be stopped).

transliteration: Oor irandu pattal koothaadi kku kondaatam
meaning: When the village is divided, it’s a celebration for the performer.
Live in harmony with the community.
If you fight with your village, you’ll be ruined elsewhere too.
Even if the world ends, never lose your determination.

transliteration: Enge pugai undoo ange neruppu undu
meaning: Where there is smoke, there is fire.

proverb: எச்சிற் கையால் காக்கை ஓட்டாதவன் பிச்சை கொடுப்பானா?
transliteration: Echchir kaiyaal kaakkai ottaadhavan picchai koduppaanaa?
meaning: One who won’t shoo a crow with his little finger will not give alms.
Begging on foot, but riding in a palanquin.
Don’t yawn at a priceless fruit.
What use is a ripe fruit or blessings from one who won't give?
One without numbers is like one without eyes.
One without literacy is like one without a neck.
For an eight-span body, the head is the main part.

proverb: எண்ணிச் செய்கிறவன் கெட்டி, எண்ணாமல் செய்கிறவன் மட்டி
transliteration: Ennish seygiravan ketti, ennaamal seygiravan matti
meaning: One who acts after thinking succeeds, the thoughtless fails.
Counting before action is business; acting without counting is farming.
Does the oil come first or the wick?
Numeracy and literacy are like two eyes.
Truth-tellers are often against the masses.
If the opponent is poor, the anger is crude.
Even if nothing else, control your tongue.

proverb: எத்தனை புடம் போட்டாலும் இரும்பு பசும்பொன் ஆகுமா?
transliteration: Eththanai pudam poattaalum irumbu pasumpon aagumaa?
meaning: No matter how much you refine, iron cannot turn to gold.
One may live by strength or by harmony.
No matter where planted, the spiny fruit is not a coconut.
Why test the bow when an archer is present?
Remove what’s burning and the boiling will stop.
Even a burning lamp needs a prop.
In a burning house, whatever you take is profit.

proverb: எரியும் கொள்ளிகளில் எந்தக் கொள்ளி நல்ல கொள்ளி?
transliteration: Eriyum kollikil endha kolli nalla kolli?
meaning: Among burning logs, which is the good one?

proverb: எருமை வாங்கும் முன்னே நெய் விலை கூறாதே
transliteration: Erumaai vaangum munne nei vilai kooradaadhe
meaning: Don’t discuss ghee prices before buying the buffalo.
Does a crow know a bull’s disease?
Will a cat release a crying rat?
Where there are rats, there will be snakes.
The rat’s trouble is the cat’s celebration.
Even for a small rat, you need a separate trap.
Can a dog that bites bones bite iron?

proverb: எல்லோரும் பல்லக்கு ஏறினால் பல்லக்கைத் தூக்குகிறவர் யார்?
transliteration: Ellorum pallakku erinall pallakkai thookkiravar yaar?
meaning: If everyone rides the palanquin, who will carry it?
Will crying clear a written debt?

proverb: எழுதியவன் ஏட்டைக் கெடுத்தான், படித்தவன் பாட்டைக் கொடுத்தான்
transliteration: Ezhudhiya van aettaik keduththaan, padiththavan paattaik koduththaan
meaning: The writer spoilt the notebook, the reader lost the song.

proverb: எழுதி வழங்கான் வாழ்க்கை கழுதை புரண்ட களம்
transliteration: Ezhudhi vazhangaan vaalkkai kazhudhai puranda kalam
meaning: A life without writing is like a field trampled by donkeys.

proverb: எழுத்தறச் சொன்னாலும் பெண் புத்தி பின் புத்தி
transliteration: Ezhuththara ch sonnallum pen puththi pin puththi
meaning: However educated, a woman’s wisdom is always second.
One who gives literacy is like God.
A poor man’s wife is everyone’s sister-in-law.

proverb: எளியாரை வலியார் அடித்தால் வலியாரை தெய்வம் அடிக்கும்
transliteration: Eli yaarai valiyaar adiththaal valiyaarai dheivam adikkum
meaning: If the strong hit the weak, God will hit the strong.

proverb: எள்ளூ என்கிறதற்கு முன்னே எண்ணெய் கொண்டு வருகிறான்
transliteration: Ellu enkiratharku munne ennai kondu varugiraan
meaning: Before sesame is mentioned, he brings the oil.

proverb: எள்ளுக்கு ஏழு உழவு, கொள்ளுக்கு ஓர் உழவு
transliteration: Ellukku ezhu uzhavu, kollukku or uzhavu
meaning: Sesame needs seven ploughings, millet only one.
An ant’s constant march can wear down a stone.
An ant can carry eight times its weight.
A gourd in the ledger doesn’t help the curry.

transliteration: Aethendru ketpaarum illai, eduththup pidipaarum illai
meaning: No one asks which it is, no one catches it.
When a tank is full, the banks will overflow.

proverb: ஏருழுகிறவன் இளப்பமானால், எருது மச்சான் முறை கொண்டாடும்
transliteration: Eruzhugiravan ilappa maanaal, eruthu machchaan murai kondaadum
meaning: If the ploughman becomes weak, the bullock’s brother rejoices.

proverb: ஏர் பிடித்தவன் என்ன செய்வான்? பானை பிடித்தவள் பாக்கியம்
transliteration: Er pidiththavan enna seivaan? Paanai pidiththaval paakkiyam
meaning: What can the one holding the spear do? Luck is for the one holding the pot.

transliteration: Eavugiravanukku vaai chsol, seygiravanukku thalai sumai
meaning: The provocateur has only words; the doer has the burden.

proverb: ஏழை அழுத கண்ணீர் கூரிய வாளை ஓக்கும்
transliteration: Ezhai azhutha kannir kooriya vaalai ookkum
meaning: A poor man’s tears can sharpen a sword.
A poor man’s speech never reaches the stage.

proverb: ஏறச் சொன்னால் எருது கோபம், இறங்கச் சொன்னால் நொண்டிக்குக் கோபம்
transliteration: Era chsonnaal eruthu kobam, iranga chsonnaal nondikku kobam
meaning: The bull is angry when told to climb, the lame is angry when told to get down.

proverb: ஐங்காயம் இட்டு அரைத்துக் கரைத்தாலும் தன் நாற்றம் போகாதாம் பேய்ச்சுரைக்காய்க்கு
transliteration: Aingayam ittu araiththu karaithaalum than naatram poagaathaam peych suraikkaikkku
meaning: Even after grinding with five spices, the gourd never loses its stench.
What doesn’t bend at five won’t bend at fifty.
Double lock for the lame dancer’s song.

proverb: ஓதிய மரம் தூணாமோ, ஒட்டாங் கிளிஞ்சல் காசாமோ?
transliteration: Oathiya maram thoonamo, ottaang kilinjal kaasaamo?
meaning: Will a dead tree be a pillar, or a broken vessel be worth coins?

proverb: ஒரு காசு பேணின் இரு காசு தேறும்
transliteration: Oru kaasu paenin iru kaasu therum
meaning: Save a penny, gain two.

proverb: ஒரு குடம் பாலுக்கு ஒரு துளி விஷம்
transliteration: Oru kudam paalukku oru thuli visham
meaning: A drop of poison can spoil a pot of milk.
Can one hand make a clapping sound?

proverb: ஒரு நன்றி செய்தவரை உள்ள அளவும் நினை
transliteration: Oru nanri seidhthavarai ulla alavum ninai
meaning: Remember the one who did you a kindness as long as you live.

proverb: ஒரு பானைச் சோற்றுக்கு ஒரு சோறு பதம்
transliteration: Oru paanai soatrukku oru soaru patham
meaning: One ladle of rice is enough to taste the whole pot.
It takes nine lies to hide one lie.
A family without unity will perish.
Discipline is the pride of a noble family.
Even in hiding, ends up in the village headman’s house.
With unity, life thrives.

proverb: ஓசை பெறும் வெண்கலம் ஓசை பெறா மட்கலம்
transliteration: Osai perum venkalam, osai peraa matkal
meaning: A sounding bell metal and a silent clay pot — appearances differ.

proverb: ஓடிப்போனவனுக்கு ஒன்பதாம் இடத்தில் குரு, அகப்பட்டவனுக்கு அட்டமத்திலே சனி
transliteration: Oadippona vanukku onbatham idaththil guru, agappattavanukku attamaththile sani
meaning: The runaway has luck, the caught one has trouble.

proverb: ஓடும் நாயைக் கண்டால் துரத்தும் நாய்க்கு இளக்காரம்
transliteration: Oadum naiyaik kandhaal thuraththum naikku ilakkaaram
meaning: The chasing dog feels pride when it sees the running dog.
When the pursuer sees the runner, it becomes easier for him.
A leaking ship needs nine sailors.
The unlearned have neither understanding nor discipline.

transliteration: Othu vaar ellam uzhuvaan thalaikkadai yilay
meaning: Even the learned end up under the farmer’s dominance.

proverb: ஓர் ஊருக்கு ஒரு வழியா? ஒன்பது வழி
transliteration: Or oorukku oru vazhiya? onbadhu vazhi
meaning: Is there only one way to a village? There are nine ways.
One village’s talk is an insult to another.
The words of a shameless person have no fear.
Even if it bathes in the Ganges, can a crow become a swan?
To those untrained, music has no appeal.
Is there anyone who can build shores for the sea?

proverb: கடலைத் தாண்ட ஆசையுண்டு கால்வாயைத் தாண்டக் கால் இல்லை
transliteration: Kadalai thaanda aasaiyundu kaalvaayai thaanda kaal illai
meaning: Wants to cross the sea but can't cross a canal.
When the sea boils, what is the worth of pond water?

transliteration: Kadal thidal aagum, thidal kadal aagum
meaning: The sea can become land, and land can become sea.
Does a sea fish need to be taught swimming?
Those who trust God will not be abandoned.

proverb: கடன் வாங்கிக் கான் கொடுத்தவனும் கெட்டான்; மரம் ஏறிக் கைவிட்டனும் கெட்டான்
transliteration: Kadan vaangik kaan koduththavanum kettan; maram yerik kaivittanum kettan
meaning: The one who borrowed to feed suffered; the one who climbed the tree and let go suffered.

proverb: கடன் வாங்கியும் பட்டினி, கல்யாணம் பண்ணியும் சந்நியாசி
transliteration: Kadan vaangiyum pattini, kalyanam panniyum sanniyasi
meaning: Having debt yet starving; married but living like a monk.
Gentle words are better than harsh ones.
Even a mustard seed of fire can burn the fence.
Even if mustard shrinks, will its spice go away?

proverb: கடுகு போன இடம் ஆராய்வார், பூசுணைக்காய் போன இடம் தெரியாது
transliteration: Kadugu pona idam aaraivaar, poosunaikkaai pona idam theriyadhu
meaning: One seeks the lost mustard, but not the lost ash gourd.

proverb: கடுங்காற்று மழை கூட்டும் கடுஞ் சிநேகம் பகை கூட்டும்
transliteration: Kadung kaatru mazhai koottum, kadun snegam pagai koottum
meaning: A heavy wind brings rain, harsh friendship brings enmity.
Harsh words destroy compassion.
Churning buttermilk to get butter.

proverb: கட்டக் கரிய இல்லாமற் போனாலும் பேர் பொன்னம்மாள்
transliteration: Kattak kariya illamar ponaalum per ponnammaal
meaning: Even if the hearth is lost, the name Ponamma stays.

proverb: கட்டிக்கொடுத்த சோறும் கற்றுக்கொடுத்த சொல்லும் எத்தனை நாள் நிற்கும்
transliteration: Kattikkoduththa soarum katrukkoduththa sollum eththanai naal nirkum
meaning: Given rice and taught words last only for a while.

proverb: கட்டினவனுக்கு ஒரு வீடானால் கட்டாதவனுக்கு பல வீடு
transliteration: Kattinavanukku oru veedanaal kattaadhavanukku pala veedu
meaning: The builder has one house, the idler imagines many.
A built house attracts eight claimants.

proverb: கணக்கன் கணக்கறிவான் தன் கண்க்கைத் தான் அறியான்
transliteration: Kanakkan kanakkarivaan than kannaith thaan ariyaan
meaning: The accountant knows numbers but not his own eye.

proverb: கணக்கன் கணக்கைத் தின்னாவிடில், கணக்கனை கணக்கு தின்று விடும்
transliteration: Kanakkan kanakkait thinnaavidil, kanakkanai kanakku thindru vidum
meaning: If the accountant doesn’t manage accounts, accounts will eat him.
Looking into accounts brings disputes.
What the eye sees, the hand will do.
Offering sun salutations after losing sight.
Even if blind, will one sleep any less?
What is seen is the sight, what is held is the beauty.
Telling what you saw may cause enmity.

proverb: கண்டால் ஒரு பேச்சு, காணாவிட்டால் ஒரு பேச்சு
transliteration: Kandhaal oru paechchu, kaanaavittaal oru paechchu
meaning: If seen, one story; if not, another story.

transliteration: Kannile kuthi na viralai kandipaar undo?
meaning: Will anyone blame the finger that pierced the eye?

proverb: கண்ணிற் பட்டால் கரிக்குமா, புருவத்திற் பட்டால் கரிக்குமா?
transliteration: Kannir pattal karikkumaa, puruvaththir pattal karikkumaa?
meaning: Does it burn if it falls on the eye or on the eyebrow?
Does the sun choose only some to burn?

proverb: கப்பல் ஏறிப் பட்ட கடன் கொட்டை நூற்றா விடியும்
transliteration: Kappal erip patta kadan kottai noottra vidiyum
meaning: A debt from boarding a ship will take ages to repay.

proverb: கப்பற்காரன் பெண்டாட்டி தொப்பைக்காரி, கப்பல் உடைந்தால் பிச்சைக்காரி
transliteration: Kappar kaaran pendantti thoppaikkaari, kappal udaindhaal pichchaikkaari
meaning: The sailor’s wife is well-off, but if the ship sinks, she is a beggar.
A sailor’s life ends when the wind changes.
A missed calculation leads to death.
Will the money from selling charcoal be black?
One who finishes the work doesn’t bother about the bundle.
Sugarcane is crushed, a fault of the mouth.
Wanted sugarcane, but got neem.
Will you uproot it for its sweet taste?
If a skilled person dissolves, even stones will dissolve.
When conflict arises, justice emerges.

transliteration: Kalladi siththan pona vazhi, kaadu medellam thavidu podi
meaning: Where the stone‑hit sage passed, forests and hills turned to dust.
Don’t wrestle with one who studied physical combat.
The uneducated are like the blind.
The learned in poverty are better than the unlearned in wealth.
Education is the truest beauty.
Wealth without education is like beauty without virtue.
Two are needed for learning, one is enough for theft.
Flawless speech is the beauty of education.
The worried cannot sleep peacefully.
Can a donkey appreciate the smell of camphor?
A crop without weeding is half a crop.

proverb: கள் விற்றுக் கலப்பணம் சம்பாதிப்பதைவிடக் கற்பூரம் விற்றுக் காற்பணம் சம்பாதிப்பது மேல்
transliteration: Kal vittruk kalappanam sampaathippathai vida karpooram vittru kaarpanam sampaathippadhu mel
meaning: Selling camphor for small change is better than selling liquor to earn.
A deceitful heart leaps with schemes.

proverb: கள்ளனும் தோட்டக்காரனும் ஒன்று கூடினால் விடியும் மட்டும் திருடலாம்
transliteration: Kallanun thottakkaaranum onru koodinaal vidiyum mattum thirudalaam
meaning: If a thief teams with a gardener, they will steal until dawn.
Is the theft bigger or the defense against it?
Why put a thorn fence around toddy?
When drunk, one speaks his mind.
The termite mound helps the snake.
What we know is a handful, what we don't is the size of the world.
A learned person is respected everywhere.
Will money seen in a dream be of any use for expenses?
A ripe fruit falls on its own.

proverb: கற்கையில் கல்வி கசப்பு, கற்றபின் அதுவே இனிப்பு
transliteration: Karkaiyil kalvi kasappu, katrapin adhuvae inippu
meaning: Learning is bitter while studying but sweet after.
Beauty without virtue is like a flower without fragrance.
Wherever the learned go, there is honor.

proverb: காசுக்கு ஒரு குதிரையும் வேண்டும், காற்றைப் போலப் பறக்கவும் வேண்டும்
transliteration: Kaasukku oru kuthiraiyum vendum, kaattraip polap parakkavum vendum
meaning: For a coin, want a horse and also to ride it like the wind.

proverb: காடு காத்தவனும் கச்சேரி காத்தவனும் பலன் அடைவான்
transliteration: Kaadu kaaththavanum kachcheri kaaththavanum palan adaivaan
meaning: Both the forest guard and the court guard reap benefits.

proverb: காட்டுக்கு எறித்த நிலாவும் கானலுக்குப் பெய்த மழையும்
transliteration: Kaattukku eritha nilaavum kaanalukku peidha mazhaiyum
meaning: The moon thrown into the forest and rain falling on a mirage are both wastes.

proverb: காட்டு வாழை வந்தால் வீட்டு வாழ்வு போகும்
transliteration: Kaattu vaazhai vandhaal veettu vaazhvu pogum
meaning: If a wild plantain enters the house, domestic happiness leaves.

proverb: காட்டை வெட்டிச் சாய்த்தவனுக்குக் கம்பு பிடுங்கப் பயமா?
transliteration: Kaattai vettich saiththavanukkuk kambhu pidungap payamaa?
meaning: Will one who felled a forest fear pulling a stalk?

proverb: காண ஒரு தரம் கும்பிட ஒரு தரமா?
transliteration: Kaana oru dharam kumbida oru dharama?
meaning: Does it take the same effort to see and to pray?
Desire for land leads to great ruin.
Laziness in farming land brings great sorrow.
A needle won’t come even with the wind unless through the right way.
Giving a safety charm reveals a weak hand.
To jaundiced eyes, everything looks yellow.
A fruitful tree gets hit by stones.
Drought ruined it, rain ruined it too.
To get the job done, catch even a donkey like a bull.
Is the task bigger or the courage bigger?

proverb: கார்த்திகை பின் மழையும் இல்லை, கர்ணனுக்குப்பின் கொடையும் இல்லை
transliteration: Karththigai pin mazhaiyum illai, Karnanukkup pin kodaiyum illai
meaning: No rains after the Karthigai month, no charity after Karna.
Time accomplishes what the world cannot.

proverb: காலம் போம் வார்த்தை நிற்கும், கப்பல் போம் துறை நிற்கும்
transliteration: Kaalam poam vaarthai nirkum, kappal poam thurai nirkum
meaning: Time passes, words remain; ships leave, ports remain.

transliteration: Kaalukkuth thakka seruppum, koolikkuth thakka uzaippum
meaning: Shoes that fit the feet, work that fits the pay.

proverb: காலளவே ஆகுமாம் கப்பலின் ஓட்டம், நூலளவே ஆகுமாநுண்சீலை
transliteration: Kaalalavae aagumaam kappalin oattam, noolalavae aagumaan unseelai
meaning: A ship’s speed and a fine cloth both depend on the smallest measure.
Only the one carrying the burden knows its weight.
Can dust fly without wind?
Winnow while there is wind.
Spit against the wind and it falls on your face.
If it’s unattainable, give it up instantly.
Escaped the well but fell into the fire.
What use is the country’s richness to a frog in the well?
Can fame satisfy hunger?
A wound heals if cut and treated.
Can the donkey carrying saffron appreciate its fragrance?
A potter needs six months, but the painter needs only half an hour.
When starving, even a horse will eat straw.
Liquor, gambling, and prostitution ruin a family.
Will you keep firewood in a house with liquor?
Even if beaten, it should be by a decorated hand.
There is no teacher who can change one’s nature.
Skill without character is useless.
Character is important, not caste.

proverb: குதிரை இருப்பு அறியும், கொண்ட பெண்டாட்டி குணம் அறிவாள்
transliteration: Kudhirai iruppu ariyum, konda pendatti gunam arivaal
meaning: One knows the horse by its gait, a wife by her nature.

proverb: குதிரை ஏறாமல் கெட்டது, கடன் கேளாமல் கெட்டது
transliteration: Kudhirai yeramal kettavai, kadan kaelaamal kettavai
meaning: A horse unused goes bad, a debt unasked goes bad.

transliteration: Kudhirai gunam arindhallavo thambiran kombu kodukkavillai
meaning: Knowing the horse’s nature, the master did not give the spear.
If the frail keeps eating, even a hill will diminish.
Garbage will rise, a tower will fall.
What’s the point of applying eyeliner to a blind eye?
One who forgets the teacher’s words strays and perishes.
Can a barking dog catch prey?
A barking dog doesn’t bite.
Caste in the garbage, money in the chest.
Learnt half the family skill, left half unlearnt.

proverb: குல வழக்கம் இடை வழக்கும் கொஞ்சத்தில் தீராது
transliteration: Kula vazhakkam idai vazhakkum konjaththil theeraadhu
meaning: A dispute between castes and families won’t end with just a talk.
A half-filled pot spills; a full pot stays steady.
A guilty heart beats anxiously.
If you focus on faults, there will be no relationships.
Where children and gods are celebrated.
Even in garbage, the red seed keeps its color.
Give respect and take respect.
A garland in a monkey’s hand.
Teaching wisdom to a monkey made the tailorbird lose its nest.

proverb: குரு இலார்க்கு வித்தையுமில்லை, முதல் இல்லார்க்கு ஊதியமில்லை
transliteration: Guru ilaarkku viththaiyum illai, mudhal illaarkku oodiyam illai
meaning: Without a guru, no skill; without capital, no wage.

proverb: குனியக் குனியக் குட்டுவான், குனிந்தவன் நிமிர்ந்தால் குட்டினவன் ஓடுவான்
transliteration: Kuniyak kuniyak kuttuvaan, kunindhavan nimirndhaal kuttinavan oduvaan
meaning: The beater keeps hitting as one bows; when he rises, the beater runs.
Living together brings a crore benefits.

transliteration: Koorai melai sooru poattaal aayiram kaagam
meaning: If food is on the roof, thousands of crows will gather.
Do not reduce wages, do not spoil the work.

proverb: கூழானாலும் குளித்துக் குடி; கந்தையானாலும் கசக்கிக் கட்டு
transliteration: Koozaanaalum kuliththu kudi; kanthayaanaalum kasakik kattu
meaning: Even if poor, bathe before eating; even if cloth is coarse, wear it neat.

proverb: கூழுக்கு மாங்காய் கொண்டாட்டம், குரங்குக்குத் தேங்காய் கொண்டாட்டம்
transliteration: Koozhukku maangai kondaattam, kurangukkuth thaengai kondaattam
meaning: Mangoes are a feast with porridge, coconuts are a feast for a monkey.
Both porridge and moustache have their own pride.
Even if ruined, education is never lost.
Impending ruin is not visible to the eyes.
One destined to perish will think destructively.

proverb: கெட்டாலும் கெட்டி கெட்டியே, கிழிந்தாலும் பட்டு பட்டே
transliteration: Kettaalum ketti kettie, kizhinthaalum pattu patte
meaning: Even if ruined, the strong remain strong; even if torn, silk is still silk.
A rogue’s flaws show within eight days.
Even when ruined, go to the city.
Put the kendai fish to catch the varaal fish.

proverb: கெரடி கற்றவன் இடறி விழுந்தால் அதுவும் ஒரு வித்தை என்பான்
transliteration: Keradi katravan idari vizhundhaal adhuvum oru viththai enbaan
meaning: A trickster who falls will call it another trick.
Victory and defeat are not the share of one person.

proverb: கேடு வரும் பின்னே, மதி கெட்டுவரும் முன்னே
transliteration: Kedu varum pinnae, madhi kettuv arum munnae
meaning: Ruin comes after, but wisdom leaves before.
Don’t believe everything you hear, don’t tell everything you believe.
A bad person has neither listeners nor followers.
Only half of hearsay is truth.
What the hand reaches may not reach the mouth.

transliteration: Kaikkolanu kku kaarpunnnum naai kku thalaippunnnum aaraa
meaning: A servant’s leg wound and a dog’s head wound never heal.
Does a hand wound need a mirror?
Without resources, even a married woman will not be respected.
Better than possessions is the true asset – education.
An unused weapon will rust.
With money in hand, food reaches the mouth.
When you have money, thousands will wait for you.
One must lean and work with tools.

proverb: கையில் பிடிப்பது துளசி மாலை, கக்கத்தில் இடுக்குவது கன்னக்கோலாம்
transliteration: Kaiyil pidippadhu thulasi maalai, kakkaththil idukkavudhu kannak kolam
meaning: Holding a sacred garland but keeping a dagger at the waist.
Is the fruit heavier than the stalk?
The receiver feels shy seeing the giver.
A tyrant’s rule will not last long.
Asking back what was given turns into enmity.
If shaken, it’s a scorpion; if not, an insect.

proverb: கொண்டானும் கொடுத்தானும் ஒன்று, கலியாணத்தைக் கூட்டி வைத்தவன் வேறு
transliteration: Kondaanum koduththaanum onru, kalyanaththaik kooti vaiththavan veru
meaning: Bride’s side and groom’s side are one, but the matchmaker is separate.
One who fears no murder fears no dishonor.
Will a needle be costly in a blacksmith’s lane?
Will a forest fox fear rustling noises?

transliteration: Kollikku ethir ponaalum, vellikku ethir pogalaadhu
meaning: One may oppose Wednesday, but not Friday.
Greater than the conqueror is the learned man.
Consider one who speaks with ill intent as a venomous scorpion.
An evil-speaking mouth is like fire with wind.

proverb: கோணிக் கோடி கொடுப்பதிலும் கோணாமற் காணி கொடுப்பது நல்லது
transliteration: Konik kodi koduppathilum konamar kaani koduppadhu nalladhu
meaning: Better than giving a crooked crore is giving a straight piece of land.

transliteration: Koththiramarinthu pennaik kodu, paaththiramarinthu pichchai idu
meaning: Give your daughter knowing the clan, give alms knowing the recipient.
Where there is anger, there is also virtue.
Anger is lowly.
Will the temple cat fear the gods?
Can a chick hatched by hen’s stomping grow into maturity?
Why worship by uttering bad words?

proverb: கோடானுகோடி கொடுப்பினும் தன்னுடைய நாக்கு கோடாமை கோடி பெறும்
transliteration: Kodaanukodi koduppinum thannudaya naakku kodamai kodi perum
meaning: Even if you give crores, controlling your tongue is worth more.

proverb: கோடானுகோடி கொடுத்தாலும் நாவினால் தவறு சொல்லாதது கோடி பெறும்
transliteration: Kodaanukodi koduththalum naavinaal thavaru sollaadhadhu kodi perum
meaning: Even after giving crores, refraining from wrong speech is invaluable.

proverb: கோடி கொடுப்பினும் குடில் பிறந்தார் தம்மோடு கூடுவதே கோடி பெறும்
transliteration: Kodi koduppinum kudil pirandhaar thammodu kooduvadhey kodi perum
meaning: Even a crore is worth less than uniting with those born in the same family.
Only what is in the pot will come to the ladle.
A fierce horse with a lame driver.
Truth will prevail, falsehood will destroy.
Is there need of a witness for a blow given at dusk?
Nakkeeran in the court, Vircheran in the kingdom (great figures in their place).

transliteration: Sambalam illaadha sevaganum, kobam illaadha esamaanum
meaning: A servant without salary and a master without anger.
Will embers fear seeing just dry leaves?
Will it become sweet just because it's called sugar?
Does simply calling it ‘sugar’ make it sweet?
If one lives in misery until death, what kind of life is that?

proverb: சாட்சிக்காரன் காலில் விழுவதிலும் சண்டைக்காரன் காலில் விழலாம்
transliteration: Saatchikkaaran kaalil vizhuvadhilum sandakkaaran kaalil vizhalaam
meaning: Better to fall at a witness’s feet than at a quarrelsome man’s feet.
One who can spin a top without a whip.
When the dirt pile rises, it slips by a foot.
If a saint gets angry, the forest won’t survive.
Drawing is also a matter of practice.
Even a small splinter can pick a tooth.

proverb: சின்ன மீனைப் போட்டுப் பெரிய மீனைப் பிடி
transliteration: Sinna meenai poattup periya meenai pidi
meaning: Throw a small fish to catch a big one.
Happiness and sorrow revolve like a wheel.
Even a bright lamp needs a stand.
Can a burnt pot know the taste?
Even if burnt, gold does not lose its shine.
Will burnt clay join with green clay?

transliteration: Sundaikkaai kaarpanam, sumai kooli mukkaar panam
meaning: Two paise for turkey berry, three paise for carrying load.

proverb: சுத்தம் சோறு போடும் எச்சில் இரக்க வைக்கும்
transliteration: Suththam sooru poodum, echchil irakka vaikkum
meaning: Cleanliness serves food, saliva makes one pity.
A pure hero values life as dust.

proverb: சும்மா வந்த மாட்டை பல்லைப் பிடித்தப் பாராதே
transliteration: Summa vandha maattai pallaip pidiththa paaraadhe
meaning: Don’t check the teeth of a cow that came free.
A lazy master gets double stripes.

transliteration: Summa kidakkira sangai ooththik keduththaan aandi
meaning: The beggar blew a conch that was lying idle.
Even if personal wisdom is lost, doesn’t one need common sense?
A wall is needed to paint a picture.

proverb: சுவாமி வரங் கொடுத்தாலும் பூசாரி இடங்கொடுக்க மாட்டான்
transliteration: Swaami varam koduththaalum poosaari idam kodukka maattaan
meaning: Even if God grants a boon, the priest may not give entry.

proverb: சூடு கண்ட பூனை அடுப்பங் கரையிற் சேராது
transliteration: Soodu kanda poonai aduppang karaiyil seraadhu
meaning: A cat once burnt stays away from the stove.

proverb: செக்களவு பொன்னிருந்தாலும் செதுக்கியுண்டால் எத்தனை நாளுக்குக் காணும்?
transliteration: Sekkazhavu pon irundhaalum sethukkiyundaal eththanai naalukku kaanum?
meaning: Even if you have a measure of gold, how long will it last if eaten away?
Will what didn’t bow as a plant bow as a tree?
The property of the dead is a refuge for the living.
Do things perfectly.

proverb: செருப்பின் அருமை வெயிலில் தெரியும், நெருப்பின் அருமை குளிரில் தெரியும்
transliteration: Seruppin arumai veyilil theriyum, neruppin arumai kuliril theriyum
meaning: The worth of shoes is known in heat; the worth of fire is known in cold.
When an elephant is stuck in mud, even crows will peck at it.
Like a lotus in the mud.
One who doesn’t know gestures knows nothing.
Will the rice seen in a dream become food?
Is the word like an arrow or the bow?
What is not spoken is not born, what is not taken does not diminish.

proverb: சொல்லாமற் செய்வார் நல்லோர் சொல்லியுஞ் செய்யார் கசடர்
transliteration: Sollamar seyvaar nallor solliyunj seyyar kasadar
meaning: The noble act without words; the flawed act even after advice.

proverb: சொல்லிப் போகவேணும் சுகத்திற்கு, சொல்லாமற் போகவேணும் துக்கத்திற்கு
transliteration: Sollip pogavenum sugaththirku, sollamar pogavenum thukkaththirku
meaning: Speak before leaving for joy; leave silently for sorrow.
The one who speaks has only words, the doer bears the burden.
It is hard to defeat an eloquent person.

proverb: சொறிந்து தேய்க்காத எண்ணெயும் பரிந்து இடாத சோறும் பாழ்
transliteration: Sorindhu theykkaadha ennaiyum parindhu idaadha sorum paazh
meaning: Oil not applied and rice not served are wasted.
A foul-mouthed child brings dishonor to the family.
A parrot-child repeats only what is told.
Laziness is the father of no food.
For a lazy man, bananas with the peel.
Do not roam lazily.
Spoiled rice is a burden to the earth.
Gold on the ground, dirt in the pot – value depends on place.
One who seeks refuge must not be betrayed.
Is one holding a stick an executioner?

proverb: தட்டிப்பேச ஆள் இல்லாவிட்டால் தம்பி சண்டப் பிரசண்டன்
transliteration: Thattippeysa aal illaavittaal thambi sanda prasanthan
meaning: Without someone to scold, the younger brother becomes arrogant.
Only a loosened bow can be restrung.

proverb: தண்ணீரிலே விளைந்த உப்புத் தண்ணீரிலே கரைய வேண்டும்
transliteration: Thanneerile vilaindha uppu thanneerile karaiya vendum
meaning: Salt produced in water must dissolve in water.
Never insult water or mother.
Even hot water will put out fire.
A son follows his father’s path.
Protect and care for parents.
One with a younger brother fears no army.
Righteousness protects the doer.

proverb: தலை இடியும் காய்ச்சலும் தனக்கு வந்தால் தெரியும்
transliteration: Thalai idiyum kaaychchalum thanakku vandhaal theriyum
meaning: Only when fever or headache strikes do we feel it.
When there is a head, can the tail lead?

proverb: தலைக்கு மேல் வெள்ளம் சாண் ஓடி என்ன, முழம் ஓடி என்ன?
transliteration: Thalaikku mel vellam saan oadi enna, muzham oadi enna?
meaning: When the flood is above the head, extra inches don't matter.
Can one defeat destiny by trickery?
If chief and officer join, theft is legal.
Meditation needs one, education needs two.
A frog is ruined by its own mouth.
A hand that came for dung will come for gold.
Charity beyond one’s means is true.
A single tree doesn’t make a grove.
One’s own hand is the best help.

proverb: தன் வினை தன்னைச் சுடும் ஓட்டப்பம் வீட்டைச் சுடும்
transliteration: Than vinai thannaich sudum, oattappam veettaich sudum
meaning: One’s own deeds burn oneself, a leaky oven burns the house.

proverb: தானம் கொடுத்த மாட்டைப் பல்லைப் பிடித்துப் பார்க்காதே
transliteration: Dhaanam kodutha maattaip pallaip pidiththu paarkaadhe
meaning: Don’t check the teeth of a cow given in charity.

proverb: தாயிற் சிறந்ததொரு கோவிலுமில்லை, தந்தை சொல் மிக்க மந்திரமில்லை
transliteration: Thaayir sirandhadhoru kovilum illai, thandhai sol mikka manthiram illai
meaning: No temple surpasses a mother; no mantra surpasses a father’s advice.
Even mother and child have separate needs.

proverb: தாய் எட்டடி பாய்ந்தால், குட்டி பதினாறடி பாயும்
transliteration: Thaai ettadi paainthaal kutti pathinaaradi paayum
meaning: If the mother jumps eight feet, the calf jumps sixteen.
Even if not given grain, still plays for meat.

proverb: தினை விதைத்தவன் தினை அறுப்பான், வினை விதைத்தவன் வினை அறுப்பான்
transliteration: Thinai vithaiththavan thinai aruppaan, vinai vithaiththavan vinai aruppaan
meaning: Sow millet, you reap millet; sow deeds, you reap results.
A jumping cow won’t carry the load.
Green from afar is pleasing to the eye.
Destroying without searching ends in trouble.
Habits from cradle to grave.
Why cut with an axe what can be scratched with a nail?
One who cannot walk chooses the busiest street.

proverb: நடந்தால் நாடெல்லாம் உறவு, படுத்தால் பாயும் பகை
transliteration: Nadandhaal naadellaam uravu, paduththaal paayum pagai
meaning: When active, everyone is a friend; when idle, even a mat becomes an enemy.
Does a planter's son need to be shown how to sow?

proverb: நண்டு கொழுத்தால் வளையில் இராது, தண்டு கொழுத்தால் தரையில் இராது
transliteration: Nandu kozhu thaal vala yil iraadhu, thandu kozhu thaal tharai yil iraadhu
meaning: A fat crab won’t fit in the net; a fat post won’t fit in the ground.
Even in a snail’s belly, a pearl can be born.
What we cannot have is like poison.

proverb: நமனுக்கு நாலு பிள்ளை கொடுத்தாலும் உற்றாருக்கு ஒரு பிள்ளை கொடுக்கமாட்டான்
transliteration: Namanukku naalu pillai koduththaalum utraarukku oru pillai kodukka maattaan
meaning: Even if given four children to Yama, he won’t give one to relatives.

proverb: நமன் அறியாத உயிரும் நாரை அறியாத குளமும் உண்டோ?
transliteration: Naman ariyaadha uyirum naarai ariyaadha kulamum undo?
meaning: Is there a life unknown to Yama or a pond unknown to the crane?
What is not possible by love cannot be done by fear.

proverb: நரிக்கு இடங்கொடுத்தால் கிடைக்கு இரண்டு ஆடு கேட்டும்
transliteration: Narikku idam koduththaal kidaikku irandu aadu kaettum
meaning: If you give the fox a place, it will ask the goat for two sheep.
The fox's feast is the crab’s misery.
Grey hair has no curtain, nor does Yama have absence.
Bad companionship leads to trouble.

proverb: நல்லது செய்து நடுவழியே போனால், பொல்லாதது போகிற வழியே போகிறது
transliteration: Nalladhu seydhu nadu vazhiye ponaal, pollaadhadhu pogira vazhiye pogiradhu
meaning: Do good and go in the middle path; evil too follows its path.

proverb: நல்ல வேளையில் நாழிப்பால் கறவாதது கன்று செத்துக் கலப் பால் கறக்குமா?
transliteration: Nalla vela yile naazhip paal karavaadhadhu kanru seththuk kalap paal karakkumaa?
meaning: If not milked in good time, can you milk after the calf dies?

proverb: நல்லவன் என்று பெயர் எடுக்க நெடுநாட் செல்லும்
transliteration: Nallavan endru peyar edukka nedunaal sellum
meaning: It takes a long time to earn a good name.

proverb: நல்லவன் ஒரு நாள் நடுவே நின்றால் அறாத வழக்கும் அறும்
transliteration: Nallavan oru naal naduvae nindraal araadha vazhakkum arum
meaning: If a good man stands in between, even an old dispute ends.
The good and the bad can be known by their conduct.

proverb: நல்ல மாட்டிற்கு ஒரு சூடு நல்ல மனிதனுக்கு ஒரு வார்த்தை
transliteration: Nalla maattirkku oru soodu nalla manithanukku oru vaarthai
meaning: One goad for a good cow, one word for a good man.
Adhere to goodness.
When the tongue moves, the whole nation stirs.
Good and evil lie in the tongue.

proverb: நாம் ஒன்று நினைக்க, தெய்வம் ஒன்று நினைக்கும்
transliteration: Naam onru ninaikka, dheivam onru ninaikkum
meaning: Man proposes, God disposes.

proverb: நாயைக் கண்டால் கல்லைக் காணோம், கல்லைக் கண்டால் நாயைக் காணோம்
transliteration: Naayaik kandhaal kallaik kaanom, kallaik kandhaal naayaik kaanom
meaning: Seeing the dog, you can't find the stone; seeing the stone, you can't find the dog.
Where there’s a dog, there’s quarrel.

transliteration: Naaykku vela illai, nirkkka neramum illai
meaning: The dog has no work, yet no time to stand.
Will the money from selling a dog bark?
A dog’s tail can never be straightened.
When small streams join, they become a large river.
Good people do not postpone today’s work.
After forty, a person’s nature won’t change.
The rabbit I caught has only three legs.
Too much familiarity breeds contempt.
An eternal land ensures full lifespan.
Can you get a monthly feast daily?

proverb: நிலத்தில் எழுந்த பூண்டு நிலத்தில் மடிய வேண்டும்
transliteration: Nilaththil ezhuntha poondru nilaththil madiya vendum
meaning: What rises from earth must return to it.
The worth of shade is known in the sun.

proverb: நின்ற வரையில் நெடுஞ் சுவர், விழுந்த அன்று குட்டிச்சுவர்
transliteration: Nindra varaiyil nedun suvar, vizhuntha anru kutti suvar
meaning: A long wall while standing, a small wall when fallen.

proverb: நிறை குடம் நீர் தளும்பாது, குறைகுடம் கூத்தாடும்
transliteration: Nirai kudam neer thalumbaadhu, kuraikudam koottaadum
meaning: A full pot is steady; a half pot makes noise.
The river carries away one who cannot swim.

proverb: நீர் ஆழம் கண்டாலும் நெஞ்சு ஆழம் காண முடியாது
transliteration: Neer aazham kandhaalum nenju aazham kaana mudiyadhu
meaning: You can know the depth of water, but not the depth of the heart.

proverb: நீர் உள்ள மட்டும் மீன் குஞ்சு துள்ளும்
transliteration: Neer ulla mattum meen kunju thullum
meaning: Fish fry only swim where water exists.
Like writing on water.
Like tears on the eyelids of the blue fruit — fleeting.
Over time, truth and lies are revealed.
Even fine thread is ruined by its own mouth.
Even the smallest task should be carefully considered.
Will anyone climb to the tip to cut the base?
Fine knowledge is as thin as thread.
The learned man has the higher place.

proverb: நூற்றுக்கு மேல் ஊற்று, ஆயிரத்துக்கு மேல் ஆற்றுப் பெருக்கு
transliteration: Noorrukku mel ootru, aayiraththukku mel aatrup perukku
meaning: Above hundred is a spring, above thousand is river flooding.
The weevil ruined the hundred measures.
Does the ghee come first or the wick?
Can long smoke rise without fire?
There’s no smoke without fire.
Will merely saying 'fire' burn the mouth?
Will a wax doll dance in a fireball?
Water meant for paddy also reaches the grass.
Those alive yesterday are gone today.
A special gift for poets.
The lame horse’s slip is an excuse.
Eating in pieces gives long life.
A healthy life is wealth without shortage.
One with disease is like one possessed by spirits.
Do not give room for disease.

proverb: பகலில் பக்கம் பார்த்துப் பேசு, இரவில் அதுதானும் பேசாதே
transliteration: Pakalil pakkam paarththup paesu, iravil athu thaanum paesaadhe
meaning: In the day, see your side before speaking; at night, speak nothing.

transliteration: Paguththariyaa mal thuniyaadhe, padapatta paaga seiyyaadhe
meaning: Do not act without understanding; don’t rush things.
Enemy friendship is like fire under smoke.
A side word can be worth ten thousand.
A hungry man does not care about taste.
When hunger comes, all ten virtues fly away.
Can raw clay stick to burnt clay?
Can cotton and fire coexist?

proverb: படிக்கிறது திருவாய் மொழி, இடிக்கிறது பெருமாள் கோயில்
transliteration: Padikkiradhu thiruvaai mozhi, idikkiradhu perumaal koyil
meaning: The sacred text is read, but the temple is crumbling.
One creates, another gives.
With an army, there is no need for a fort.
Even in the battlefield, connections help.

proverb: பட்ட காலிலே படும் கெட்ட, குடியே கெடும்
transliteration: Patta kaalile padum ketta, kudiyE kedum
meaning: When hit at the root, the whole family suffers.

transliteration: Pattaa un perile, saagupadi en perile
meaning: The title in your name, but cultivation in my name.

proverb: பட்டுக்கோட்டைக்கு வழி கேட்டால், கொட்டைப் பாக்கு விலை சொல்லுகின்றாய்
transliteration: Pattukottaikku vazhi kaettal, kottaip paakku vilai sollugindrai
meaning: Asked the way to Pattukottai, you tell areca nut’s price.

proverb: பட்டும் பட்டாடையும் பெட்டியிலிருக்கும், காற்காசு கந்தையில் ஓடி உலாவும்
transliteration: Pattum pattadaiyum pettiyil irukkum, kaarkaasu kanthaiyil oadi ulaavum
meaning: Silks stay in the box, coins roam in the pocket.

proverb: பணக்காரன் பின்னும் பத்துப்பேர், பைத்தியக்காரன் பின்னும் பத்துப்பேர்
transliteration: Panakkaaran pinnum paththup per, paiththiyakkaaran pinnum paththup per
meaning: Ten people follow the rich man, ten follow the mad man too.
Do you consider wealth or tradition?
Money can do all ten things.
If there is money, there will be marriage.
Money in the chest, character in the garbage.
The more you do, the more variety comes.
The virtue is known from the crop you sow.
A calm job never scatters.
A plantain without fruit hanging in the shed.
Before the feast, there is the preparation.
For ten, a spoon; for one, a head load.
One born in Parani can rule the earth.

proverb: பருத்திக்கு உழும் முன்னே தம்பிக்கு எட்டு முழம்
transliteration: Paruththikku uzum munne thampikku ettu muzham
meaning: Before ploughing for cotton, give your brother eight measures.
Farm in the right season.
Many drops make a flood.
A thief escapes for many days, but will be caught one day.

proverb: பல மரம் கண்ட தச்சன் ஒரு மரமும் வெட்டமாட்டான்
transliteration: Pala maram kanda thachchan oru maramum vettamaattaan
meaning: A carpenter who’s seen many trees might not cut even one.

proverb: பல்லக்கு ஏய யோகம் உண்டு, உன்னி ஏறச் சீவன் இல்லை
transliteration: Pallakku eya yogam undu, unni erach seevan illai
meaning: There is fortune for a palanquin, but no life to board it.

proverb: பல்லார் முனியப் பயனில சொல்லுவான், எல்லாரும் எள்ளப்படும்
transliteration: Pallaar muniyap payanila solluvaan, ellaaarum ellappadum
meaning: Speaking uselessly before many earns everyone’s ridicule.
When teeth are gone, words change.
Too much familiarity turns even milk sour.

proverb: பழி ஒரு பக்கம், பாவம் ஒரு பக்கம்
transliteration: Pazhi oru pakkam, paavam oru pakkam
meaning: Blame is one side, sin is another.
The raw leaf laughs at the ripe leaf’s fall.
Will a ripe fruit stay on the branch?
Don’t pinch the child and then rock the cradle.
A foolish king has a witless minister.
The wise man is the strong man.
Will one born to a tiger become a cat?
Calm comes after the storm.
A tiger crouches as a sign of its leap.

proverb: பூ மலர்ந்து கெட்டது, வாய் விரிந்து கெட்டது
transliteration: Poo malarnthu kettadhu, vaai virinthu kettadhu
meaning: A flower spoilt after blossoming, a mouth spoilt after opening.
Patience must be like the earth.
Will the money from selling flowers smell sweet?
The cat’s celebration is the rat’s hardship.
The thread with the flower also gets fragrance.
Even demons pity a woman.

proverb: பெண்டு வாய்க்கும் புண்ணியவானுக்கு, பண்டம் வாய்க்கும் பாக்கியவானுக்கு
transliteration: Pendu vaaykkum punniyavaanukku, pandam vaaykkum paakiyavaanukku
meaning: A virtuous man gets a wife; a lucky man gets wealth.
A woman’s curve straightens only in gold.

transliteration: Penn endru pirandha pothu purudan pirandhiruppaan
meaning: When a woman is born, her mate is also born.
A woman raised is like a gourd creeper (delicate & needs support).
As long as the deity is present, festivals will come.
Respect and shame come from the mouth.

proverb: பெற்ற மனம் பித்து, பிள்ளை மனம் கல்லு
transliteration: Petra manam piththu, pillai manam kall
meaning: A parent’s heart is tender, a child’s heart is stone.
Speaking more removes the shyness.
If you don’t speak, you won’t err.
Greed brings great loss.

proverb: பேர் இல்லாச் சந்நிதி பாழ், பிள்ளை இல்லாச் செல்வம் பாழ்
transliteration: Per illaa sannidhi paazh, pillai illaa selvam paazh
meaning: A temple without deity is empty, wealth without child is void.

proverb: பொங்கும் காலம் புளி, மங்கும் காலம் மாங்காய்
transliteration: Pongum kaalam puli, mangum kaalam maangai
meaning: In prosperous times tamarind, in declining times mango.

proverb: பொய் சொல்லி வாழ்ந்தவனுமில்லை, மெய் சொல்லிக் கெட்டவனுமில்லை
transliteration: Poi solli vaazhnthavanum illai, mey solli kettavanum illai
meaning: No one prospers by lies, no one perishes by truth.
A lying mouth gets no food.
The patient rule the world, the angry rule the forest.
One who conquers a spark becomes master of wisdom.
Patience is greater than the sea.
Gold vessels make no sound, brass vessels do.

proverb: பொன் ஆபரணத்தைப் பார்க்கிலும் புகழ் ஆபரணமே பெரிது
transliteration: Pon aabaranaththaip paarkkilum pugazh aabaraname peridhu
meaning: Fame is a greater ornament than gold jewelry.

proverb: போதும் என்ற மனமே பொன் செய்யும் மருந்து
transliteration: Pothum endra maname pon seyyum marundhu
meaning: A mind that says ‘enough’ is the medicine that turns to gold.

proverb: போரோடு தின்கிற மாட்டுக்குப் பிடுங்கி போட்டுக் கட்டுமா?
transliteration: Porodu thingira maattukku pidungi poattuk kattumaa?
meaning: Will you tie up a cow that eats during war?
One who broods over what’s lost is a fool.
Only with valuables in the lap is there fear on the way.
Simple food gives peace of mind.
Will you enter a river trusting a clay horse?
As long as there is a head, phlegm never ends – problems remain as long as life.
Best not to cross the doorway of the wise uninvited.
A drum has thunder on both sides.
A minister’s beauty is in meaningful speech.
Even a minister can lose respect.

proverb: மரம் வெட்டுகிறவனுக்கு நிழலும், மண் தோண்டுகிறவனுக்கு இடமும் கொடுக்கும்
transliteration: Maram vettugiravanukku nizhalum, man thondugiravanukku idamum kodukkum
meaning: A tree gives shade to its cutter, the earth gives space to its digger.
One who plants a tree will water it.
For the fearful, every shadow is a ghost.
Medicines and feasts are taken three times a day.
Even medicine should be taken like a feast.
Cheap goods end up in the marketplace.
Isn’t a small chisel enough to pierce a mountain?
If you spit upwards, it will fall on your chest.
Silence can end a quarrel.

proverb: மழைமுகம் காணாத பயிரும் தாய்முகம் காணாத பிள்ளையும்
transliteration: Mazhaimugam kaanaadha payirum thaaymugam kaanaadha pillaiyum
meaning: A crop that hasn’t seen rain and a child that hasn’t seen mother are alike.
Even after the rain stops, the drizzle continues.
A fool speaks the secrets in his heart.
There is no cure for stubbornness.
Where there is will, there is a way.
When the mind falters, the opponent gains strength.
Life is as the mind perceives it.
As is the king, so are the subjects.
If the upper floor falls, the hall will follow.
Even if a cow is old, does milk lose its taste?

proverb: மாடு கெட்டால் தேடலாம், மனிதர் கெட்டால் தேடலாமா?
transliteration: Maadu kettal thedalaam, manidhar kettal thedalaamaa?
meaning: If a cow is lost, it can be searched – but if a man is lost, can he be searched?

proverb: மாடு மேய்க்காமற் கெட்டது, பயிர் பார்க்காமற் கெட்டது
transliteration: Maadu meikkaamar kettadhu, payir paarkkaamar kettadhu
meaning: A cow untended and a field unwatched both spoil.
What the mother withholds, the mango tree provides.

proverb: மா பழுத்தால் கிளிக்காம், வேம்பு பழுத்தால் காக்கைக்காம்
transliteration: Maa pazhuthaal kilikkaam, vaembu pazhuthaal kaakkaikkaam
meaning: When the mango ripens, parrots come; when neem ripens, crows come.
A mother‑in‑law is also just another house’s daughter‑in‑law.

proverb: மாமியார் உடைத்தால் மண் குடம், மருமகள் உடைத்தால் பொன்குடம்
transliteration: Maamiyaar udai thaal man kudam, marumagal udai thaal ponkudam
meaning: If the mother‑in‑law breaks it, it’s a clay pot; if the daughter‑in‑law breaks it, it’s a golden pot.

proverb: மாமியார் மெச்சின மருமகளில்லை, மருமகள் மெச்சின மாமியாரில்லை
transliteration: Maamiyaar mechchina marumagal illai, marumagal mechchina maamiyaar illai
meaning: No daughter‑in‑law ever liked by the mother‑in‑law, and vice versa.
The wages placed safely in the lap.

proverb: மாரிக்காலத்தில் பதின்கல மோரும், கோடைக்காலத்தில் ஒருபடி நீரும் சரி
transliteration: Maari kaalatthil pathinkala moorum, kodaik kaalatthil orupadi neerum sari
meaning: In rainy season ten pots of buttermilk, in summer a measure of water is equal.
Without rain, there is no farming.
A sweet that suits the flour.
Give no place to the enemy.
Which is greater – honor or life?
Showing a deer to catch a deer.
One should not travel west with excess baggage.
All that glitters is not gold.
Is there a snake that does not bite those who step on it?
Lightning is often followed by rain.
A ship without a captain cannot sail.
Do not desire leftover food.
A mirror is face to face.

transliteration: Mukkaa lum kaagam muzhugik kuliththaalum kokkaagumaa?
meaning: Even if a crow bathes thrice, will it become a crane?
Only the hen laying eggs knows the pain.
Can a lame man wish for palmyra tree honey?
Neither the crocodile nor the stubborn leave what they have caught.
First defect is the whole defect.

proverb: முத்தால் நத்தைப் பெருமைப்படும், மூடர் எத்தாலும் பெருமை படார்
transliteration: Muththaal naththaip perumaipadum, moodar eththaalum perumai padaar
meaning: A snail boasts with a pearl; a fool never gains pride no matter what.

proverb: முப்பது வருடம் வாழ்ந்தவனும் இல்லை, முப்பது வருடம் தாழ்ந்தவனும் இல்லை
transliteration: Muppadhu varudam vaazhnthavanum illai, muppadhu varudam thaalndhavanum illai
meaning: No one has always been on top or always been at the bottom for thirty years.
Will a drumstick tree become a pillar if it grows thick?
If a cloth is on thorns, pull it back carefully.
Remove a thorn with a thorn.
What is done in the morning yields results in the evening.
For those fully drenched, what is more wetness?

proverb: முன் ஏர் போன வழிப் பின் ஏர்
transliteration: Mun eer pona vazhip pin eer
meaning: The second plough follows the first plough’s path.
If the forearm lengthens, so will the elbow.
Can you place the back foot ahead of the front foot?

proverb: முன்னவனே முன் நின்றால் முடியாத பொருள் உளதோ?
transliteration: Munnavane mun nindraal mudiyadha porul uladho?
meaning: If the chief stands in front, is anything impossible?
Words of elders are nectar.

transliteration: Meichchollik kettavanum illai, poisolli vaazhnthavanum illai
meaning: No one suffers from speaking truth, no one prospers by lies.
Slow flowing water wears away stone.
Even a crow near Meru appears golden.

proverb: மேற்கே மழை பெய்தால் கிழக்கே வெள்ளம் வரும்
transliteration: Maerkae mazhai peithaal kizhak ke vellam varum
meaning: If it rains in the west, floods come in the east.
Don’t tie knots on a bald head and knees.
One who errs in speech errs in path.

proverb: மோகம் முப்பது நாள், ஆசை அறுபது நாள்
transliteration: Moham muppadhu naal, aasai arupadhu naal
meaning: Desire lasts thirty days, greed lasts sixty.
Silence can conquer a mountain.

proverb: யானை இருந்தாலும் ஆயிரம் பொன், இறந்தாலும் ஆயிரம் பொன்
transliteration: Yaanai irundhaalum aayiram pon, irandhaalum aayiram pon
meaning: An elephant is worth a thousand gold even alive or dead.
Even an elephant sometimes stumbles.

proverb: யானைகொரு காலம் வந்தால், பூனைக்கொரு காலம் வரும்
transliteration: Yaanai koru kaalam vandhaal, poonai koru kaalam varum
meaning: When the elephant has its time, the cat too gets its time.

proverb: யானை வரும் பின்னே மணி ஓசை வரும் முன்னே
transliteration: Yaanai varum pinne mani osai varum munne
meaning: The sound of the bell precedes the elephant’s arrival.
Deceit ruins life.

proverb: வடக்குப் பார்த்த மச்சு வீட்டைப் பார்க்கிலும் தெற்குப் பார்த்த குச்சு வீடு நல்லது
transliteration: Vadakku paartha machchu veettai paarkilum theerkku paartha kuchchu veedu nalladhu
meaning: A northern-facing face is praised, but a southern-facing house is better.
Thought leads to rain in the north.
Greed for interest is the root of evil.
A thorn that is worshipped still pricks.
If income is eight, expenses are ten.
Limit expenses according to income.
If one grieves, nothing is impossible to come.
Wisdom is to prepare before things happen.
For the capable, even grass is a weapon.
A capable one will find a worthy rival in the world.
Even the wealthy should know limits.

proverb: வழவழத்த உறவைப் பார்க்கிலும் வைரம் பற்றிய பகை நன்று
transliteration: Vazhavazhathth uravaip paarkkilum vairam patriya pagai nanru
meaning: Better is the enmity over diamond than a twisted kinship.
What you give should be like what you expect to receive.
A child with a mouth will survive.
Sweet words and soft hands are like ailments.
Life is lost due to bad words.
Living and dying are due to the mouth.
Life and downfall last for some time.
Live and let live.
If the sky lies, the earth moves.
As is fate, so is wisdom.
There is medicine for disease, but is there medicine for fate?
What cannot be done by wish, can it be done by compulsion?

proverb: விரை ஒன்று போடச் சுரை ஒன்று முளைக்குமா?
transliteration: Virai onru podach surai onru mulaikkumaa?
meaning: Can one twig sprout if the vine is not set?

proverb: வில்வப்பழம் தின்பார் பித்தம் போக பனம் பழம் தின்பார் பசி போக
transliteration: Vilvappazham thinpaar piththam poga panam pazham thinpaar pasi poga
meaning: Those who eat bael fruit cure bile; those who eat fruit cure hunger.
Does a lamp change hands without flickering?
What started as a game ended in mischief.
The crop’s yield is known at the sprout.

proverb: வினை விதைத்தவன் வினை அறுப்பான், தினை வினைத்தவன் தினை அறுப்பான்
transliteration: Vinai vidaiththavan vinai aruppaan, thinai vinaiththavan thinai aruppaan
meaning: The doer reaps what he sows, the seed sower reaps the harvest.
Rat at home, tiger outside (danger everywhere).
One cut becomes two pieces.
Can one match the length of a hand span with a little finger?
Not all that’s white is milk.
A dam should be built before the flood comes.
